src/QueryPath/QueryPathExtension.php

00001 <?php
00002 /** @file
00003  * This file contains the Query Path extension tools.
00004  *
00005  * Query Path can be extended to support additional features. To do this, 
00006  * you need only create a new class that implements {@link QueryPathExtension}
00007  * and add your own methods. This class can then be registered as an extension. 
00008  * It will then be available through Query Path.
00009  *
00010  * For information on building your own extension, see {@link QueryPathExtension}.
00011  * If you are trying to load an extension you have downloaded, chances are good that
00012  * all you need to do is {@link require_once} the file that contains the extension.
00013  *
00014  * @author M Butcher <matt@aleph-null.tv>
00015  * @license http://opensource.org/licenses/lgpl-2.1.php LGPL or MIT-like license.
00016  * @see QueryPathExtension
00017  * @see QueryPathExtensionRegistry::extend()
00018  */
00019 
00020 /** @addtogroup querypath_extensions Extensions
00021  * The QueryPath extension system and bundled extensions.
00022  *
00023  * Much like jQuery, QueryPath provides a simple extension mechanism that allows 
00024  * extensions to auto-register themselves upon being loaded. For a simple example, see
00025  * QPXML. For the internals, see QueryPathExntesion and QueryPath::__construct().
00026  */
00027 
00028 /**
00029  * A QueryPathExtension is a tool that extends the capabilities of a QueryPath object.
00030  *
00031  * Extensions to QueryPath should implement the QueryPathExtension interface. The
00032  * only requirement is that the extension provide a constructor that takes a
00033  * QueryPath object as a parameter.
00034  *
00035  * Here is an example QueryPath extension:
00036  * <code><?php
00037  * class StubExtensionOne implements QueryPathExtension {
00038  *   private $qp = NULL;
00039  *   public function __construct(QueryPath $qp) {
00040  *     $this->qp = $qp;
00041  *   }
00042  *
00043  *   public function stubToe() {
00044  *     $this->qp->find(':root')->append('<toe/>')->end();
00045  *     return $this->qp;
00046  *   }
00047  * }
00048  * QueryPathExtensionRegistry::extend('StubExtensionOne');
00049  * ?></code>
00050  * In this example, the StubExtensionOne class implements QueryPathExtension.
00051  * The constructor stores a local copyof the QueryPath object. This is important
00052  * if you are planning on fully integrating with QueryPath's Fluent Interface.
00053  *
00054  * Finally, the stubToe() function illustrates how the extension makes use of 
00055  * QueryPath internally, and remains part of the fluent interface by returning
00056  * the $qp object.
00057  *
00058  * Notice that beneath the class, there is a single call to register the 
00059  * extension with QueryPath's registry. Your extension should end with a line 
00060  * similar to this.
00061  *
00062  * <b>How is a QueryPath extension called?</b>
00063  *
00064  * QueryPath extensions are called like regular QueryPath functions. For 
00065  * example, the extension above can be called like this:
00066  * <code>
00067  * qp('some.xml')->stubToe();
00068  * </code>
00069  * Since it returns the QueryPath ($qp) object, chaining is supported:
00070  * <code>
00071  * print qp('some.xml')->stubToe()->xml();
00072  * </code>
00073  * When you write your own extensions, anything that does not need to return a 
00074  * specific value should return the QueryPath object. Between that and the 
00075  * extension registry, this will provide the best developer experience.
00076  *
00077  * @ingroup querypath_extensions
00078  */
00079 interface QueryPathExtension {
00080   public function __construct(QueryPath $qp);
00081 }
00082 
00083 /**
00084  * A registry for QueryPath extensions.
00085  *
00086  * QueryPath extensions should call the {@link QueryPathExtensionRegistry::extend()}
00087  * function to register their extension classes. The QueryPath library then 
00088  * uses this information to determine what QueryPath extensions should be loaded and
00089  * executed.
00090  *
00091  * @ingroup querypath_extensions
00092  */
00093 class QueryPathExtensionRegistry {
00094   /**
00095    * Internal flag indicating whether or not the registry should
00096    * be used for automatic extension loading. If this is false, then
00097    * implementations should not automatically load extensions.
00098    */
00099   public static $useRegistry = TRUE;
00100   /**
00101    * The extension registry. This should consist of an array of class
00102    * names.
00103    */
00104   protected static $extensionRegistry = array();
00105   protected static $extensionMethodRegistry = array();
00106   /**
00107    * Extend QueryPath with the given extension class.
00108    */
00109   public static function extend($classname) {
00110     self::$extensionRegistry[] = $classname;
00111     $class = new ReflectionClass($classname);
00112     $methods = $class->getMethods();
00113     foreach ($methods as $method) {
00114       self::$extensionMethodRegistry[$method->getName()] = $classname;
00115     }
00116   }
00117   
00118   /**
00119    * Check to see if a method is known.
00120    * This checks to see if the given method name belongs to one of the 
00121    * registered extensions. If it does, then this will return TRUE.
00122    *
00123    * @param string $name
00124    *  The name of the method to search for.
00125    * @return boolean
00126    *  TRUE if the method exists, false otherwise.
00127    */
00128   public static function hasMethod($name) {
00129     return isset(self::$extensionMethodRegistry[$name]);
00130   }
00131   
00132   /**
00133    * Check to see if the given extension class is registered.
00134    * Given a class name for a {@link QueryPathExtension} class, this 
00135    * will check to see if that class is registered. If so, it will return
00136    * TRUE.
00137    * 
00138    * @param string $name
00139    *  The name of the class.
00140    * @return boolean
00141    *  TRUE if the class is registered, FALSE otherwise.
00142    */
00143   public static function hasExtension($name) {
00144     return in_array($name, self::$extensionRegistry);
00145   }
00146   
00147   /**
00148    * Get the class that a given method belongs to.
00149    * Given a method name, this will check all registered extension classes
00150    * to see if any of them has the named method. If so, this will return 
00151    * the classname.
00152    *
00153    * Note that if two extensions are registered that contain the same 
00154    * method name, the last one registred will be the only one recognized.
00155    *
00156    * @param string $name
00157    *  The name of the method.
00158    * @return string
00159    *  The name of the class.
00160    */
00161   public static function getMethodClass($name) {
00162     return self::$extensionMethodRegistry[$name];
00163   }
00164   
00165   /**
00166    * Get extensions for the given QueryPath object.
00167    *
00168    * Given a {@link QueryPath} object, this will return
00169    * an associative array of extension names to (new) instances.
00170    * Generally, this is intended to be used internally.
00171    *
00172    * @param QueryPath $qp
00173    *  The QueryPath into which the extensions should be registered.
00174    * @return array
00175    *  An associative array of classnames to instances.
00176    */
00177   public static function getExtensions(QueryPath $qp) {
00178     $extInstances = array();
00179     foreach (self::$extensionRegistry as $ext) {
00180       $extInstances[$ext] = new $ext($qp);
00181     }
00182     return $extInstances;
00183   }
00184   
00185   /**
00186    * Enable or disable automatic extension loading.
00187    *
00188    * If extension autoloading is disabled, then QueryPath will not 
00189    * automatically load all registred extensions when a new QueryPath
00190    * object is created using {@link qp()}.
00191    */
00192   public static function autoloadExtensions($boolean = TRUE) {
00193     self::$useRegistry = $boolean;
00194   }
00195 }
